text:
In South Korea, huge wild fires have been burning for more than a week, but in recent hours, rain has given the emergency services some hope. 

The fires have been spreading fast due to dry conditions and strong winds but rainfall may help put out some of the flames. 

Thousands of people have had to leave thier homes and move to temporary accommodation and schools in the area are closed. 

Firefighters and military personnel have been involved in tackling the fires, with more than 120 helicopters in action.

summary: Reaction to Scotland's Nations League defeat by Greece, with the Scots heading to League B in the next cycle.
text:
Ryan Christie: "We're frustrated, especially with how well the first leg went.

"Coming in tonight we saw it going a lot differently. We probably didn't create enough and they were pretty cut-throat going forward themselves. Overall a very frustrating night at Hampden but we've got to pick ourselves up for the friendlies in the summer.

"We're not naive enough to know we're going to have it all our way. There's been plenty bumps in the road and this is probably going to be one of them. It's about now how we react from this and bounce back hopefully get ourselves in a really good place going into the qualifiers.

Kenny McLean: "Difficult to take. We put so much into the first leg and knew they were a good team.

"The goals are so disappointing on our behalf and we didn't create enough either. To work so hard to get into the position we were in and kind of throw it away there is really disappointing.

"We need to get better. We're going to play Greece in the near future so we know we cannot underestimate them in the slightest."

John McGinn: "We started pretty well, had a couple of chances, we just let ourselves down with the first goal we conceded. We've got to reflect now before two friendlies in the summer.

"It's an embarrassing night for us, everyone is flat in the stadium, we let ourselves down.

"No threat in behind, probably too easy to pick up. Greece deserved to win. That will maybe give us a kick up the backside for the World Cup qualifiers - we know they are no mugs.
title: Hirst says Scotland will be 'ready' for Greek revenge & more Scotland reaction

Heathrow Airport is back in action after it temporarily closed due to a power outage on Friday.

The airport in London, is the busiest in Europe. As many as 200,000 people travel through it every day, to get from the UK to countries all over the world.

On Friday the airport lost its electricity because of a fire at a nearby electric substation, which provides power for the area, forcing it to close.

With thirteen hundred flights affected, many people in the UK and around the world had trips cancelled or delayed, including children on school trips or visiting family abroad.

That left kids like these stranded.

summary: The former chief executive of the SNP for 24 years has appeared in court charged with embezzlement. What do we know about him?
text:
From the outset, contender Ash Regan said Mr Murrell's position as SNP chief executive was a "clear conflict of interest".

And this theme would not go away with another candidate, Kate Forbes, questioning the integrity of the electoral process.

What led the chief executive to go was linked to a row about party membership and who would be voting in this election.

One point of pride for Mr Murrell had been his campaign to increase followers after the failed Scottish independence referendum of 2014 and the coronation of his wife as leader and first minister.

The SNP went from a membership of less than 25,000 in 2013 to more than 125,000 by December 2019.

But that figure had fallen back to 72,000 by March 2023 and the party only reluctantly confirmed this when media and opposition pressure, plus questions from all three candidates, became too much.

The power couple who helped shaped Scottish politics in the first two decades of this century were no more. In January, the couple announced that they were to end their marriage "with heavy heart", having been separated "for some time". 

The police have since confirmed that Sturgeon and former SNP treasurer Colin Beattie are no longer under investigation.

Earlier this month Sturgeon announced she was to stand down as an MSP.
title: Peter Murrell: One half of Scotland's power couple

summary: BBC's Ione Wells reports from Brazil where rainforest, animals and local people are being affected by the new road.
text:
A huge four-lane highway is being built in the Amazon rainforest, destroying protected areas. 

The new road is being built for the COP30 climate summit in the Brazilian city of Belém, which will host the environmental conference in November.

With around 50,000 people, including world leaders, expected to attend, the local government is trying to improve access and facilities in the city, and says it's being done in a sustainable way. 

But many critics say cutting down trees and destroying the rainforest habitat of many animals will have a lasting impact on the area. 

The BBC's Ione Wells reports from Brazil.
title: Amazon rainforest being destroyed for road to climate summit

Sweet tubs are not usually recycled by councils so Teddy decided to collect them himself. 

With the help of family and friends he collected more than 2,500 plastic tubs which were sent to a special plastic processing plant. 

Teddy then had the opportunity to find out what happened to the tubs next.

summary: Advice from an expert who’s been in the room with the Russian leader.
text:
What do we know about President Trump’s long term strategy when it comes to dealing with Russia, and where does that leave America’s relationship with Europe and Ukraine? 

Justin, Sarah and Anthony get an inside view from Celeste Wallander, one of Biden and Obama’s top security staffers who has been in meetings with Vladimir Putin.

How does the Russian leader behave during negotiations, and what advice does she have for the Trump administration? 

We also look at what Trump’s reset of US/Russia relations means for Europe, and the war in Ukraine.

summary: Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams speak about their time in space, and planned return to Earth in the spring.
text:
Remember Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams? They're the two Nasa astronauts who blasted off into space last summer and have been stuck there ever since.

The pair were supposed to visit the International Space Station for just eight days - but eight months later, they're still there due to a problem with their return aircraft. 

Butch and Suni are due to return to Earth in the spring, but a specific date is yet been given. 

In a special news conference they've been speaking about what they'll miss when they finally return to their home planet.
title: What will stranded astronauts miss most about space?

summary: Members from the Brit Award-winning jazz band Ezra Collective went to their old school to deliver a special surprise. Newsround was invited along to find out what happened...
text:
It's been an exciting start to the year for jazz band Ezra Collective, with the group picking up the award for Best British group at the Brits. 

After they collected the famous gold statue on stage, they spoke about how important it is for kids to learn music and be given instruments.

Ricky went to meet band members Femi, TJ and Joe, as they delivered a surprise to their old school.
title: 'This moment right here is because of the great schools'
